abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Enterprise Sector
            Adjustment Program (PESAP) Project in Mauritania are as
            follows: overall outcome of the project satisfactory,
            performance of the Bank was rated as satisfactory, and the
            performance of the Borrower was rated as good. Four main
            lessons can be drawn from the PESAP implementation
            experience. First, economic liberalization does not
            necessarily translate into competitive markets and private
            sector development, but may lead to private monopolies, if
            the liberalization process is not accompanied by appropriate
            measures to ensure fair competition between the
            entrepreneurs involved - both public and private. Second,
            experience of the PESAP also stresses the need for a
            prefeasibilty study which should help assess and design the
            most appropriate conditions to implement a divestiture
            program. If such a study had been carried out during the
            preparation of the PESAP, it would have clearly identified
            the peculiarities of certain mixed-economy companies and the
            constraints to be addressed in order to facilitate their
            divestiture within a more realistic timeframe. Third, in
            rehabilitating public enterprises, financial restructuring
            is not an end by itself. If in the meantime the enterprise
            management does not implement forceful reforms to improve
            the management system and the enterprise productivity and to
            significantly reduce its operating costs, the financial
            restructuring would have little impact in the long run. Last
            but not least, within the framework of public enterprise
            (PE) sector adjustment operations, important resources are
            sometimes allocated directly to enterprises to carry out
            their financial restructuring. In this context the Bank
            should be more demanding on the quality of management and
            design explicit criteria to monitor enterprise performance
            improvements. The signing of a "contract-plan" is
            not a sufficient criteria to ensure that an enterprise will
            effectively implement the reforms required to restore its
            profitability. It should be reinforced by specific
            performance objectives whose satisfactory achievement should
            also be reflected in the legal covenants or conditional
            ties, as appropriate.
